title: Induced emf - loops near increasing current wire

content.question: Three identical, circular wire loops are placed near a current carrying wire, as shown in the figure. Loop <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is placed perpendicular to the wire, which passes through its center. Loop <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is placed to the side of the wire such that the plane of the loop is parallel to, but does not contain, the wire. Loop <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is placed directly above the wire and the plane of Loop <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> contains the wire. The centers of loops <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are equidistant from the wire. If the current in the wire is increasing, which of the following correctly ranks the induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math>’s <math alttext="script uppercase E sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="script uppercase E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="script uppercase E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>, in each of the loops <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="script uppercase E sub A is less than script uppercase E sub B, which is less than script uppercase E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="script uppercase E sub A equals script uppercase E sub B, which equals script uppercase E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>=</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>=</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="script uppercase E sub A equals script uppercase E sub B, which is less than script uppercase E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>=</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo><</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>

<math alttext="script uppercase E sub A is less than script uppercase E sub C, which is less than script uppercase E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo><</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo><</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="script uppercase E sub A equals script uppercase E sub B, which is less than script uppercase E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>=</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo><</mo></mstyle><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
